Centre for Research in Primary and Community Care</depositr>         <depDate date="2013-12-10T00:00:00Z">10 December 2013</depDate>         <distDate date="2014-03-06T00:00:00Z">6 March 2014</distDate>       </distStmt>       <verStmt>         <version date="2014-03-06T00:00:00Z">1</version>       </verStmt>       <holdings URI="http://dx.doi.org/10.5255/UKDA-SN-7434-1" />     </citation>     <stdyInfo>       <subject>         <keyword>2012</keyword>         <keyword vocabURI="http://lod.data-archive.ac.uk/skoshasset/2c09c7b0-0b0f-4d26-ba0f-45956a0ad519">CLEANING</keyword>         <keyword vocabURI="http://lod.data-archive.ac.uk/skoshasset/c4571ad7-e3f1-47a6-aa04-b35393d183c3">DOMESTIC APPLIANCES</keyword>         <keyword vocabURI="http://lod.data-archive.ac.uk/skoshasset/31026b94-bd6d-42fe-94ea-2694f7c4fa0d">DOMESTIC RESPONSIBILITIES</keyword>         <keyword vocabURI="http://lod.data-archive.ac.uk/skoshasset/f339e8ee-b3bd-42a2-b57f-c093faf16d8d">FAMILY LIFE</keyword>         <keyword vocabURI="http://lod.data-archive.ac.uk/skoshasset/7ae86014-b439-4a39-bbc0-edebaa5dc387">FOOD CONTROL</keyword>         <keyword vocabURI="http://lod.data-archive.ac.uk/skoshasset/20d00d58-637d-4ee9-8824-0daa799b3a13">FOOD RESOURCES</keyword>         <keyword vocabURI="http://lod.data-archive.ac.uk/skoshasset/87dd1bb8-45ac-468b-851c-0e0bc54c09f6">KITCHENS</keyword>         <keyword vocabURI="http://lod.data-archive.ac.uk/skoshasset/4a821930-5499-4bb4-b058-ab0ae3c8746b">UNITED KINGDOM</keyword>         <topcClas>Social attitudes and behaviour - Society and culture</topcClas>         <topcClas>Elderly - Social stratification and groupings</topcClas>         <topcClas>Family life and marriage - Social stratification and groupings</topcClas>         <topcClas>Gender roles - Social stratification and groupings</topcClas>       </subject>       <abstract><p>Abstract copyright UK Data Service and data collection copyright owner.</p>This is a qualitative data collection. This study was designed to investigate, document, analyse and interpret domestic kitchen practices to generate insights about 'what goes on and why' in UK kitchens, to inform the Food Standards Agency's (FSA) thinking about how to reduce the burden of foodborne disease. A key focus of earlier FSA research has been on reported behaviours \ufffd\ufffd\ufffd the Kitchen Life study took a different approach, to examine what people do, what they say about what they do and the role of the kitchen itself and its assorted things, technologies and resources (chopping boards, microwaves and cupboards, for example). A qualitative and ethnographic approach was taken to investigate domestic kitchen practices in 20 UK households. The practices of those aged 60+ years and pregnant women were of particular interest to the FSA as these groups are vulnerable to foodborne illness; these household-types were therefore included in the study. Whilst the study used several qualitative methods to collect data, including video-observation and photo-elicitation, only anonymised transcripts from audio-recorded informal interviews are being deposited in the archive, due to issues of anonymity with the visual data.<br> </abstract>       <sumDscr>         <timePrd event="start" date="2012-06-01T00:00:00Z">June 2012</timePrd>         <timePrd event="end" date="2012-12-01T00:00:00Z">December 2012</timePrd>         <collDate event="start" date="2012-06-01T00:00:00Z">June 2012</collDate>         <collDate event="end" date="2012-12-01T00:00:00Z">December 2012</collDate>         <nation>United Kingdom</nation>         <geogUnit>No spatial unit</geogUnit>         <anlyUnit>Families/households</anlyUnit>         <universe>National</universe>         <universe>UK households</universe>         <dataKind>Textual data</dataKind>       </sumDscr>     </stdyInfo>     <method>       <dataColl>         <timeMeth>Follow-up to cross-sectional study</timeMeth>         <dataCollector>Meah, A., University of Hertfordshire.
